Enlist today and spread managed democracy to the stars.

The servers issues seem to be mostly fixed now, had no trouble playing with friends at peak weekend hours this week. The game is still a bit buggy, but mostly in minor, irritating ways rather than anything critical.

Overall, this is a very good sequel to the first game, the change in perspective is a bit jarring at first and does make some things work less well (its harder to see enemies that are about to call in reinforcements, for example) but overall it makes the game more atmospheric and makes orbital strikes easier to target and feel immediately more relevant.

Probably the biggest issue it has now is that the balance seems very poor - Automatons are much tougher than Terminids and some guns and stratagems appear to be total trash, while others are almost compulsory to take (especially on certain missions or difficulty levels). While there are quite a few things to unlock in theory, the process is very grindy and it's disappointing to find that most of the options available to you are actually pointless. In practice, most players will end up selecting the same narrow combinations over and over - which risks the game feeling pretty stale and repetitive.
Requested a refund until the game is playable.
I'm doing my part!

The devs fixed almost all of the server issues. All the remains now are some intermittent crashing issues, however this issue also seems to have been slightly improved.

Besides that, you know the story with this game. You've seen it all over social media, it's as good as it looks. Half terminator Vietnam sim, half Starship Troopers the game. Just buy it please.
Come on, You APES, You wanna live forever?

For those with AMD RX 7000 series cards, you can usually fix the constant crashes if you switch to using DirectX 11, but that is not an in-game option, you have to add a parameter through steam.

The game uses a kernel level rootkit anti-cheat, just to protect a microtransaction cosmetics store in a PvE game. Talk about pathetic.

Weeks after launch and the game still has bugs, like not letting certain players spawn back in, your third person camera being knocked to orbit by explosions, models being stuck in places.

Matchmaking is still atrocious, even on the days it works. There are a lot of maps where people deploy SOS beacons, then nobody can join them. 200k players online, and not finding a single match? Must be a user mistake.

Solo play gives less rewards than group play.

You need 1500 medals to unlock the basic set of stuff in game, which takes about 200 mission, ranged from 10 to 40 minutes each.
And of course the stronger weapons that you actually want to use and don't take up one of your precious 4 stratagem slots are pay-walled behind real money, then you still need even more medals (about 400?).
BEST GAMES OF 2024 SO FAR!

Helldivers 2 carries the spirit of the first game very well,

There are notable gameplay changes and some factors have made the game easier ( enemies don't go ham and spawn endlessly or on the entire map, but there are at times random counterattacks on your squad )

The limited amount of weapons and lack of upgrades for said weapons might make you sad at first , but I hope more weapons and stratagems will be introduced in future DLC

But I am finding both the bugs and cyrborgs interesting to fight.

The only negative pet peeve might be the occasional random crash, rare disconnect from a lobby, nonsensical ragdolling ( the extraction shuttle got hit with a drop pod and was launched across the map, we couldn't get on and that was funny) , and the occasional chinese hacker

If you want to get this game then consider it a mash between Tom Clancy's breakpoint and Starship troopers or just play the first game.

I enlisted because, 
One night when I was 12 years old, I had awoken from a horrific nightmare around 2am. It was so terrifying that I had to leave my bedroom and go sit in an armchair in my family’s living room. I did this to console myself and reinforce that the nightmare wasn’t real. As I began to calm down, slow my breathing and wipe away the single tear from my face, a cockroach came out from under the armchair and tickled the back of my right ankle. I jumped from the armchair some 50 feet across the living room. Reality then became my living nightmare! Since then, I have had an irrational fear of cockroaches.

A few years later the movie Wall-E had come to theaters. I enjoyed the move so much that I ran out to the local toy store and spent all my money on the Wall-E robot. I rushed it home and immediately unboxed it. I was so excited; it was my first RC toy. It was then that I discovered the controller it came with would only allow the toy to go forwards and turn to the right. It could not go backwards.  You had to turn it right 180 degrees and then go forward to return it to where it to where came from. To make a left you had to turn it to the right 270 degrees. You also could not have it go forward and right at the same time, you had to stop the robot to make the right turn. You also had to move the arms manually! I was devastated! 

So, for me….

This war…

IS PERSONAL!

I became a Helldiver, to squish bugs and hammer robots with democracy!

If you skip the PSN stage, and have Crossplay turned on it soft-locks you out of the game. 
(New Edit At Bottom, explaining how to fix my issue.)

Edit: Have tried every method my friend has sent to me to try and fix it but since this is a "Always online game" those fixes just don't work, at all, and nothing can fix it, I've reached out to the support team, but I'm thinking that there is no fix to this problem as many other users are coming up on the same problem and haven't gotten an answer to fix it, So I will probably end up refunding a second time since my friends thought they were so smart, and have been proven wrong with each attempt at fixing this game for me.

P.S. Next time don't add a Skip button to the most important part of your game to get it to work.

Edit 2 (Game Works): After 53 minutes and a lot of fiddling around with Files thanks to a friend mentioned above, My game now works, You just have to go into 
C:\Users[Username]\AppData\Roaming\Arrowhead\Helldivers2 
Locate the "user_settings.config" file 
And Delete it. (I recommend also deleting any files in the saves folder as well, since there shouldn't be anything there if you couldn't get into the game.) 
If you were having the same problem as me, good luck, hope you get it working as well.

Edit 3: Can't join any lobby, Tried for 80 minutes just getting into friends games. (It just doesn't work.)
I'm about done with Arrowhead Games. Waste of $80 CAD until THEY fix the issue, give this game a solid F.

Edit 4: Than you BubleWoot on Youtube for showing how to fix said problem I was having, you need to Turn off IPV6, this makes the multiplayer function. Can Now Play online.

I'm not sure about this game. I'm a few hours in but I don't really understand all the hype. Yes it is decent to kill time with friends, but decent is pretty much all I can say about the game. Graphics are nice but the combat itself with mouse/keyboard doesn't feel very responsive. The mini map and how it works, you can tell this was a console game ported to PC and it lacks a few of those PC features to make it really a nice user experience.

Content wise, I don't really see what drives people to play this over and over. It doesn't feel very rewarding to keep on playing similar mission after similar mission. Maybe this just isn't for me and the game is decent but it should't be more than a 6.5-7 out of 10 and it for sure is very much overhyped. This feels like a 20 dollar game for me, not worth triple A money.

I have to split this review into two fundamental parts.

The first is how the game is currently, which is superb. I liked the first game quite a bit but got into too late in it's life cycle to appreciate the grand scale. This game lets me rectify that mistake, and appreciate that the studio still has the talent and quality that made Magicka 1 one of my favorite games of all time to just play and introduce friends to. It's repetitive, enemy types are somewhat varied, and maps are randomly generated. I still love it, I'm still going to keep playing it, and I've already gotten what I feel is my money's worth out of this purchase. There's no predatory monetization, the battlepass is not FOMO or time limited, and the premium currency can be farmed and earned rather easily with no expenditure but time and effort on your part.

This is, ideally, how a live service game should function. Which leads to the second part; my future view of this game is going to depend on how quick and how substantial new toys and things to fight are added in. From the time of this review at the end of February I've heard rumors of monthly updates, which would be a very brisk pace. If this comes true, then I will be singing this games praise for some time to come.

If not, then I can still atleast recommend it as an easily enjoyable third person shooter with extremely based and redpilled and ultra democratic stuff in it. Any other opinion is undemocratic and will be reported immediately to the Democracy Officer.

[b][i]HELLDIVERS™ 2[/i] is one of the best games created in recent years.[/b] It is fun, complex, challenging and stuffed with many interesting mechanics. I love the level design and overall visual aesthetics. Thanks to them the [b]game is beautiful and every planet gives you a different experience.[/b] I will not mention the gunplay - it is perfect.

The game has few flaws and problems - I want to add that compared to other big publisher products [i]HELLDIVERS™ 2[/i] is in great shape. It is playable, and the developers are working to improve the game, their attention to the player base is impressive. Other problems are bad balance and lack of content, but trust me they are not something gamebraking.

I really recommend this game to anyone willing to try it out. But remember to bring someone along to anihilate ugly bugs and creepy automatons.

A quick note I will review this again and adjust my rating when this game fixes its issues. I do not recommend it as it is right now, the missions can vary from decent to annoying, notably the evacuation of civilians as a standalone mission as an example. The issues go beyond gameplay and level design, there are too many bugs to count that cause issues such as CTD, and frozen loading screens during mission landing loading scenes. Save yourself the frustration, and give this game a chance later when it is fixed. Don't believe the blind hype you see from fanboys and social media. The game can get rather annoying with its issues ruining the decent gameplay that exists.

edit: extra mention, team killing is a serious issue in this game.  Trolls absolutely love to abuse it, it goes from funny to annoying as its purposefully done by the player base.

Helldivers 2 is a great game that you shouldn't buy. The gameplay is fun and hits on nostalgia for Starship Troopers and The Terminator but I can't suggest it when you can't really play the game itself due to all the roadblocks and developer neglect regarding servers and general crashes. Wait a few weeks for the issues to get patched because right now the devs are sweeping server issues under the rug. This is not a good look for a new game. If they were going to knowingly release Helldivers 2 without the server space, they should have limited keys and at the least slapped an Early Access tab on it.

An actual quote from the creative director - "If you have no cash, get it later. While we made a really fun game it’s worth waiting until the servers can support the capacity. I mean, as a CEO I of course want the game to be as profitable as possible, but if you spent your last $ and got stuck in server queues I’d be [heartbroken]."

Edit: I got about five minutes of gameplay in two hours. Yikes.
Edit 2: Helldivers 2 lack of optimization is roasting AMD 7900 series GPUs. Play at your own risk.
Edit 3: Server issues are fixed but AMD builds are still crashing and causing PC damage. Most AMD full system crashes are happening at ship entry or extraction. 
Edit 4: Hit 50 crashes today.

If you haven't seen a Paul Verhoeven film, should you decide to, they will remind you of this game. (Although for us old folks it's the other way around.) Specifically Starship Troopers and Robocop, both amazing satires, but anything he did from '87-'97 will do (Yes, I include Showgirls). 

I don't know how the long term progression will be, I know there's a cap on how many Requisition points you can hoard and limited options to spend them on. The ability to earn sufficient super credits IN GAME as opposed to whaling and buying them for cash is great. It really cuts down on that FOMO need to buy, but gives those the opportunity to do so if they desire. 

Best played with a friend or three, Solo is possible but definitely not the way to go. Difficulty definitely ramps up, but with the strategem progression and your experience you can climb the ladder. Most mid to late ship upgrades require samples only obtainable in SUICIDE MISSION or higher difficulties, if that tells you anything.

This game is designed to be played with others, and it's fantastic if you have a full team of friends. Although there were some issues at launch, and a few persist, I don't mind them much as I'm thoroughly enjoying myself with friends.

However, [b]if you plan to play matchmaking, get ready to dive into hell[/b]. Toxicity reigns as the major issue of this game. Friendly fire adds an element of fun until teammates intentionally team-kill you. The game's design encourages death and diving again, but your team may opt not to hit that revive button for the next 30 minutes... Even worse, the host holds godlike power over you. Should they find amusement in kicking you after a 40-minute session, denying you any rewards, you are doomed. Fortunately, there's a vocal chat feature that can help identify griefers early, particularly when they start hurling insults in the lobby.

Although the problem has been reported to the development team, their response indicated that such issues are inherent to online gaming, and they have no plans to address them. Surely they know how to design a real dive into hell.

Helldivers 2 propels players beyond the stars into a cosmic battleground where the fight for democracy knows no bounds. In this sequel, the call to arms echoes across the vast expanse of space, and every gamer is a crucial Helldiver in the galactic uprising.

The visuals in Helldivers 2 are nothing short of stellar, capturing the awe-inspiring beauty and treacherous perils of deep space. From nebulas to hostile alien worlds, the graphics immerse players in a visually stunning universe, making every mission a breathtaking journey.

Gameplay is a symphony of chaos and strategy as you navigate the cosmos, facing extraterrestrial threats in the pursuit of spreading democratic ideals. The urgency of the mission is palpable, urging players to be at their tactical best in the face of interstellar challenges.

The cooperative multiplayer aspect takes center stage, emphasizing the need for solidarity in the fight for freedom. Helldivers 2 is a powerful reminder that democracy is not confined to earthly realms, and every Helldiver is a beacon of hope in the vast darkness of space.

One of the best shooters/coop games I've played and a middle finger to greedy game publishers:
PROS:
+ Really intense, immersive, explosive, and hilarious gameplay
+ Literally the Halo ODST sequel/spin-off game we never got from 343, BUT DESERVE.
+ Game is hilarious to play with friends (EXPECT LOTS OF TEAM KILLING)
+ Great variety of weapons, stratagems (including airstrikes, nukes, power weapons, orbital lasers, etc), and variety of alien bugs/robots to use them on.
+ Feels like a beautiful homage to other classic scifi series like Halo, Warhammer 40k, Terminator, and especially Starship Troopers
+ A huge amount of attention to detail (both visually and with gameplay)
+ Incredible music
+ Lots of replay value between the progression and the various planets/missions to play on
+ The live war map is a cool way to not only make every match feel impactful as you can track every planet & how liberated it is, but also help make the replay value borderline addicting and adds more of a live narrative to the game with new planets and events popping up every day (THIS IS HOW YOU DO A LIVE SERVICE)
+ Game does have both a free and paid battle pass, but not only is the pass not linear about what you unlock first, but you can earn in-game credits and everything from the pass by just playing the game and at a reasonable rate that won't make you feel pressured to spend anything (THIS IS HOW YOU DO A BATTLE PASS)
+ Arrowhead have already been updating and patching the game at a consistent rate and have been very transparent and informative about the game since launch. (THIS IS HOW YOU INTERACT WITH YOUR COMMUNITY)
+ Game feels worthy of full price, but is only $40
+ MANAGED DEMOCRACY APPROVED!!!

CONS:
- Servers have had issue with max capacity and players not being able to log in. The devs have been vocal about fixing this, and honestly, they have made many great steps on making the issue less frequent. Game is a rare case of suffering from success as they didn't expect it to be a massive mainstream hit and have even said, "Hold off on buying until the issues are fix" which is really cool of them. While I've personally noticed the issues not present anymore, you might still run into this so warning about that.
- Occasional bugs and crashes
- While the armor you unlock is badass, there's no way to change the colors like in games like halo. So if you want to mix and match helmets with different body armor, just know it might not look the best.
- Not super informed about this (and honestly not that concerned either), but it's worth noting this game apparently uses a certain anti-cheat program some weren't happy about. If that seems like something you're concerned about, I'd look into it, but honestly, I haven't had any issues so it doesn't seem like a big deal to me.

I'm not mad, Arrowhead Game Studios I'm just disappointed. I had issues with the game crashing at random times while on the ship right out of the tutorial. I started doing what I know to do: check temps, reinstall GPU drivers, admin, quick search said turn off xyz settings, launched one match when it seemed stable. Finish mission, game crashes while waiting for the transport. Take time to really look at stuff online, go through a ton of fixes, installed process lasso, and tested each "fix." Coming up on two hours applied the dx11 fix and it -seems- like that did it? Then I kind of thought about it: if this doesn't work? I'll feel like I -need- to figure out what's going on to get my money's worth out of it. Not that $40 is a lot, but on the principal that if I give you money for a game? I should be able to play it. It's just such a shame, the game seems fun but I'm just so tired of messing with shit like this. I considered just trying it and if it wasn't working just waiting for an update, but who knows when / if that'll happen (the game industry isn't exactly a beacon of trust these days)? Plus by the time it -is- working I'm sure most of my friends will have seen most or all of the content, which really kills a lot of the fun for me because I play multiplayer games like this one to have that first "oh shit" moment with my friends. Thanks for a thrilling Saturday night, Arrowhead Game Studios. I hope you all (individually) get a brain freeze while stepping on a Lego barefoot.

Are you ready to do YOUR part for democracy?

In the far-flung future, where the galaxy teems with godless creatures who have never tasted the sweet, liberating nectar of democracy, "Helldivers 2" beckons YOU to bring peacekeeping to a whole new level. Be shot out of your Super Destroyer like the democracy-delivering hero you were born to be, and land on the barren, alien-infested wastelands crying out for liberation!

"Helldivers 2": The Game That Redefines Heroism

Forget those so-called "AAAA" titles. "Helldivers 2" is a masterclass in intergalactic warfare, with orbital strikes so precise, they'd make the enemies of freedom weep tears of sheer admiration—if they had tear ducts, that is.

Do you adore team-based shooters? Have a penchant for the classics like "Starship Troopers," "Terminator," and "Aliens"?

Then, for the love of democracy and all that is holy in the galaxy, enlist today and immerse yourself in the unparalleled adventure that is "Helldivers 2." Equip yourself with the most advanced gear, unlock cheat-code-level stratagem powers, and engage in a progression system that will see you championing democracy across a variety of mission types. From strategic destruction to daring rescues, to facing waves of enemies eager to turn your armor into a fashion statement—this game has it all.

The Future is Bright for "Helldivers 2"

As we look to the horizon, filled with the promise of new battles, new victories, and an ever-expanding universe under the banner of freedom, "Helldivers 2" stands as a beacon of hope and excitement for what's to come.

Enlist Today!

Purchase your ticket to the stars, download "Helldivers 2," and as you wait, enjoy a comforting cup of Liber-Tea. Then, gear up, Helldiver, and dive headfirst into the fray. Democracy isn't going to spread itself, after all.

For Glory! For Freedom! For Super Earth!

Become the Hero the Galaxy Deserves.

The developers have been great about improving servers to handle the game's unexpected and rapid surge in popularity. They have also been good about fixing bugs as they are reported.
Still a few issues, it's basically the tail-end of an early access game, approaching release-version polish within the next few months.
There are microtransactions and battlepasses, which I'd normally dislike, BUT in this game the battlepasses never expire, so they don't make you feel like you are forced to play out of FOMO, they are just another way to fund the development of the game long term without feeling parasitic or inhumane. The game doesn't make you feel pressured at all. Additionally, the real money currency can be earned in game, and you can buy the premium battlepass with that currency.
So I think, considering the reasonable entry price of the game, they have an overall good attitude towards monetisation for a live service game, for now at least.

Graphics are great, very much latest gen AAA level quality. Animations and physics are great, combat feels physical and visceral. Premise is simple but there is a lot of depth on offer, which makes a nice change from e.g. Ubisoft and Bethesda games where there is a broad and complex premise, but absolutely no depth on offer.

Most importantly, it's a lot of fun, and having nine difficulty levels built into level selection instead of a game menu, makes changing the difficulty feel like an essential part of progress, instead of something you do simply when you aren't good enough or after you start finding things too easy. The whole recipe just works astoundingly well. Rock solid game, and it deserves all the popularity it has. Well done developers.

Game is really fun.

Imagine being an ODST, dropping in from orbit and landing on the enemy, crushing them with the sheer force and speed of your drop pod. Cortana asks if you could make any more noise, and you silently mock her by calling in a cluster bomb airstrike on a singular enemy, [i]because fuck those guys [/i]. 

You race towards the objective, gather some found currency along the way, and make it back to extract just in time to finish the game and take a pee break after being fueled on Mt. Dew like you're the Hulkster on lime green steroids.

That all sounds pretty cool, right?

It sure would be, [i] if you could get into a lobby [/i]. But hey, that just means everyone else is doing their part. Now wait in the queue so you can have your turn to go die in a brutal space massacre from your own team dropping orbital bombardments on you carelessly at worst, or trying to trick shot land on you when dropping from orbit at best.

Welcome to Space Hell, soldier. I hope you like it, because it's the only mode in the game.

The game has come a long way since its first issues, and I'm really enjoying it now. One of the aspects I appreciate the most is its non-pay-to-win model, which is centered around cosmetics. It's rewarding to know that all the cool items are earned through gameplay rather than bought. Plus, I love the variety of stratagems, planets, weapons, and cosmetics available. The balance between the free and paid battle passes is also well done, with the free pass offering just as much value, if not more, than the paid one. Overall, it's a great game that keeps me coming back for more.

so many issues are present, whether its the fact it takes 35 real life minutes to get into the main menu, or the piss poor optimization, or the bug that prevents you from respawning, or the bug where you dont get your primary weapon, or the game punishing you for both moving too much and staying still too long at the same time, the gameplay faults of scientist extraction missions being so poorly designed that its just not even fun and the elimination missions taking a grand total of 13 seconds to complete.

at the same time, having 3 friends battle through hell alongside you is something that has been replicated in many games, but none of which have done it as good as HELLDIVERS 2. this game is the definition of "better with friends" because if you dont have friends to play it with you might want to consider drinking tar and eating cinderblocks because youll get a very similar experience from doing either of those. however if you do have friends this game can be some of the most fun shit anyone can ever play. this is not worth the money yet, but it definitely will be once they fix the fucking issues that make me want to shove caltrops up my urethra.

I played the first game quite a bit so was quite keen to play this when I saw it was coming, but then I saw the camera angle was changing and thought I'd rather watch a review after launch and decide then if I still want it. 

It looked amazing and the reviews were great as well, so I thought I'd buy it for my wife and I to play together. Today was the first time we played it and have to say, it's been so disappointing. 

Right out the door, I had to attempt the tutorial 3 times because the portion that teaches you about crouching kept spawning too low, so it looked like you needed to prone to get past it, but were unable to. It worked for my wife, which is the only reason I knew it was spawning too low. After Alt+F4'ing a couple of times, it finally spawned at the right height for me and I was able to go ahead with the tutorial. 

Half way through it, the game crashes. My wife's was fine so I thought it must be my PC. I checked and there were driver updates available so I went ahead and did them. Got back in the game and guess what, the crouching section of the tutorial had spawned too low again. Alt+F4 and try again and it works, I manage to get through the whole tutorial. 

Get into the game and try invite my wife to my session. "No friends online" yet hers says that I am a friend and online... Decide to join her game instead, no big deal. A bit of a bumpy start but now we're in the game and playing, all of the above has taken just over an hour and we have not played anything other than the tutorial yet. 

We get into our first mission, and get about half way through before her game crashes. Okay, so not just my PC. I tell her to check for drivers, surprise, she has the same updates available as I did. She does them and gets back in the game. We finish the mission and start the next one. Another crash from my game. 

We try multiple times and keep taking turns with the game crashing, do some research and see that many people are having the same issue. One guy says "Try running as admin from the game files and in windows 8 compatibility mode" so I try it. Drastically increases the stability of the game, we manage to play 2 full games without an interruption. 

Third game however, I get kicked because of network problems... I reconnect and try again. Seems we were just lucky earlier because we continued having multiple crashes each again after that without being able to complete a single mission. We keep just reconnecting to each other to continue the mission. 

We decide to take a break and try again later. 

3 hours later, we try again but now "Servers are at capacity, try again later" - We tried many times and were unable to get in. It's actually quite disgusting and has made me not want to play the game at all. Takes all the excitement out of it. I am the first of my friends to try this game, and I will be the last. I will wait a week or so and try again, and then change my review if the problems are resolved. If not, I will try get a refund. Hoping it will be fine since the product simply doesn't work.

I just keep coming back to this game. I've done over 100 drops and still every single one feels like something unique and different. A blast to play with friends and strangers alike. Honestly this is the first game I've mic chatted with randoms in YEARS since the community is mostly pretty great.

Highly recommended and well worth the price.

"Why I Now Have Trust Issues: A 'Helldivers 2' Saga"

Let me paint you a picture: You, your friends, and a galaxy that desperately needs some democracy. Sounds noble, right? Enter "Helldivers 2," the game that takes that noble picture, throws it into a blender, and serves it to you with a side of chaos and a sprinkling of betrayal.

This game is the digital equivalent of "trust fall" exercise gone horribly wrong. One minute you're a well-oiled machine of galactic liberation, the next you're screaming at your friend because they just dropped a tank on your head. Again. You start off with high hopes of strategic gameplay, only for it to devolve into a circus of misfires, friendly fire, and the kind of chaos that makes you question your friendships.

Playing "Helldivers 2" is like participating in a comedy of errors, but with guns. And bugs. Lots of bugs. The kind that laugh in the face of your carefully laid plans and feast on the chaos that ensues when your buddy accidentally calls an airstrike on the team’s position instead of the enemy's.

The game's brilliance lies in its ability to seamlessly blend intense action with moments of pure, unadulterated pandemonium. One second you're heroically defending a position, the next you're accidentally gunning down your teammate because they ran in front of your bullet stream like some kind of adrenaline-junkie squirrel.

And let's talk about the "strategems." Oh, the strategems. These are supposed to be tactical game-changers. Instead, they often change the game by how spectacularly they backfire, turning would-be victories into slapstick tragedies. You haven't lived until you've seen a teammate frantically try to outrun their own misplaced orbital strike.

In conclusion, "Helldivers 2" is a masterclass in controlled chaos. It's a game that will have you laughing one moment and facepalming the next. If you love the thrill of battle, the agony of defeat, and the sweet, sweet taste of chaos, then congratulations, you're in the right place. Just remember, in "Helldivers 2," trust is a commodity as scarce as your chances of a smooth mission. Strap in, it's going to be a bumpy ride.

I have had nothing but fun playing Helldivers 2. It had a kinda rough launch with server capacity issues but Arrowhead has worked relentlessly to fix the problem and so far have been successful at it. Arrowhead has gone against the industry standard of live service games by making the real money currency earnable in game and at fair price points for the people who would rather just buy it. Their battlepass costs around 10 dollars when almost any other game I've played that has implemented the battle pass system usually charges $20+. The gameplay loop is a lot of fun especially if you have friends to play the game with. It has a good difficulty curve that allows all levels of people to enjoy the game from people who want turn their brain off and shoot bugs to the people who want to tear their hair out levels of tough. The graphics are great and so is the games music. Solid 9/10.

Original 

If you own a 7900xtx or other AMD products, I recommend you avoid this game until the issues are fixed.

I had a blast when I was able to play. First crash was at the end of the training. Had to skip it.

Every mission I played included a crash that wiped the progress. This was a driver error, which crashed multiple applications on my desktop.

Common fixes I found on steam and Reddit include setting to full screen and taking off vsync. This causes a black screen on launch, and server issues to boot meaning it is completely unplayable.

---

I will update if it gets better, but I've elected to refund. With games like this, if it isn't fixed soon, by the time it is friends will be less likely to want to play, therefore limiting the fun factor by a severe margin.

Becoming a Hell Diver was the greatest choice of my life. I get to see beautiful and planets all while spreading democracy and freedom to the galaxy. Joining the Hell Divers made me tall, rich, and handsome. This message was approved by the Ministry of Truth.

What I remember about Malevelon Creek was how quiet it was when we landed. It was dark, foggy, eerie. Spotting an enemy base in the distance my squad made our way up the hill to take it. Before any of us could take a shot, a stationary gun blew us away. Blown off our feet, we were injured but miraculously we were alive. However that was only the start of our nightmare, as hordes of Bots descended upon us, relentless, unfeeling, seemingly endless. 
We knew it was going to be a long night. It was a miracle any of us survived it with our sanity intact.

Don't let the mixed reviews fool you, the game had a rough launch not because it was too bad, but because they didn't expect the game to be so popular it crashed their servers for almost 2 weeks. Arrowhead spent almost every other day patching the servers to increase stability and capacity.

The concept: You and up to a squad of 4 people go down to a planet (map) and complete objectives. Then after completing the main objectives, you call for a dropship to extract/rescue you.

The core of what sets this game apart from others are two things:
1. Stratagems - you can request support from your cruiser up in high orbit. This can be in the form of requesting an orbital barrage, eagle airstrike, sentry guns, or equipment. Calling down support needs you to input a set of commands (Up, Right, Down, Down, Right for example for a cluster bomb). Part of the challenge is performing a calldown during a hectic fight.
2. The atmosphere - if you've ever dreamed of being in Starship Troopers versus a wave of bugs, Imperial Guard in Warhammer 40k against impossible odds, Stormtrooper in the Clone Wars saga versus the bots, or the last Resistance versus Skynet, this is the game. No game makes you feel so powerful yet so weak. But when you get a mission done on Helldive with the timer running out, being chased by 5 bile titans as your team is doing laps waiting for extract, fighting down until your ammo is out and you're screaming for more cluster bombs - you'll realize this game is gold.

Other things
1. Friendly Fire - is always on. Given you can call for massive AOE, have access to high explosives and weapons, part of the challenge in a hectic fight is trigger discipline and communication.
2. The movement - you can crouch, slide, dive, and go prone. This sounds basic but when combined with friendly fire avoidance, this becomes key in not getting shot by your teammates trying to shoot that hostile right next to you. You also take less damage when prone.
3. The enemies - right now there are 2 factions that you fight against, bugs and bots. Fighting against bugs feel like playing a totally different game when fighting bots. The game is expected to add 2 more factions.

Finally, the music is great, from the moment you drop down from high orbit to the final extraction theme, it adds a lot into the game.

TLDR: Buy the game. With friends. Get a mic. Have fun.

Game is great for its price and sets another example to what AAA games should aim for instead of whatever they're doing to games now. The severs are improving for some people, and recently have been getting in with no issue at peak times. [b]Cut the Team some slack, they were not anticipating their game to be this popular. Give them time to fix their game. [/b] For the price, it's a fun time and addicting gameloop. You and a group of 3 others are expendable, tasked to completing your operation or die trying. No p2w weapons, expensive skins, or battlepass to be seen here. There's sort of a "battlepass" system, but it's more progressive of things you can purchase with in-game currency. You can even earn real currency through normal gamplay without needing to be frugal about what you can spend your money on. I managed to buy multiple things from the Superstore and still made enough SuperCredits to buy the premium pass with less grinding than GTAO. The satire is great and very similar to Starship Troopers as you destroy robots and bugs. Still, the game is rough in areas, which could be irritating and adding more difficulty to the game than is was intended.
The list below are some negatives of the present bugs and normal gameplay.

[h3]Negatives[/h3]
[list]
    [*] Annihilator Tanks makes zero audio when they're not shooting. I've accidentally run head first into them many times when they're not aggressive and just idling around in the tree line. No engine or tread noises? Weird.
    [*] Both Terminids and Automaton patrols are super frequent even when you've destroyed their outpost.
    [* ]Both Terminids and Automaton patrols literally spawn in your face or within 50m. Even multiple spawn, seemingly heading in your direction. How convenient for them.
    [*] Both Terminids and Automatons are inconsistent on when you call-in Stratagems in their area. They'll either not care about their impending doom, or will immediately call reinforcements which is another issue.
    [*] Both Terminids and Automatons call reinforcements too quickly and too frequently leading to multiple encounters which is a wasting your time and resources. Been multiple occasions where we were shooting one that is about to call-in reinforcements for them to only tank shots or been completely hidden and signal anyway.
    [*] Sometimes unable to pick up samples and other items that you have dropped from death or just naturally spawned in the mission.
    [*] Some times the extraction will glitch out and you won't be able to get in.
    [*] Damn enemy explosives are so strong. They're way too accurate and the knockback from the explosion is insane. They can shoot your cover and fling you away from it. You'll be hit way more by rockets than bullets.
    [*] Armor is currently bugged. Light, Medium, and Heavy doesn't change your defense. It only affects your speed.
    [*] Calling a hellbomb on a Detector Tower is impossible. The Stratagem ball bounces and rolls away from the tower and lands too far.
    [*] If you're near one of your team mates and they get spotted, you also get spotted even if they never got line of sight on you.
    [*] Absolutely can't control your pod sometimes when you have some braindead player throw you on a Bile Titan. Which doesn't kill them either.
    [*] It seems only certain operations are only available on certain difficulties. Bummer you have to experience a different operation on a different difficulty, but makes sense to have a specific operation to destroy a Hulk/Tank/Bile Titan on lower difficulties.
    [*] Some guns could use a buff because the Breaker Shotgun, and SMG are just way too good to not use.
[/list]

Mainly the core issues are the patrols and them calling reinforcements. It's just way too much, way too often. It gets ridiculous how fast it takes for one to call reinforcements, and have it snowball into a "random" patrol spawning behind you, getting engaged from behind now, have another patrol come out of nowhere, to have them call reinforcements, to repeat the cycle constantly. The best strategy is running away, and even running away, they'll spawn around you so frequently. It also makes no sense why enemies spawn on a point of interest you've cleared already.

It does seem like a lot of negatives with hardly any positives to show for, but the game is really excellent in what it does. From cooperating with your team, using certain stratagems to compliment or cover each other, how you strategize with your team on how to tackle situations, sound design, and atmosphere. It's simple fun with not difficult mechanics (apart from sprinting into things makes you automantle by accident, please add into settings).

This game is best described with this one story I have to tell:

I, and three friends, drop into a difficulty 7 (suicide) mission.
We land next to a Detector Tower, where we couldn't for the life of us get a Hellbomb close enough to it to destroy it as the beacons would bounce like bouncy balls and go 30 odd meters away from it and leave it out of range.
We struggle in this hellhole of a planet with so much dust in the air you can't even see your own two feet while more lasers are being shot at us than during the entirety of the starwars franchise.
35 mintues (but where it felt like 3 hours) later we get to extraction.
30 seconds until the ship lands so we can GTFO a tank shows up.
I instantly unload all my Auto Cannon shots straight into it, which seemed to only piss it off, only for my friend to drop back in after dying on top of it, killing it, he comes up out of his tube, looks dead at me, salutes and shouts "DEMOCRACY"... at which point the tank explodes sending him flying through the air, over the extraction point, 200 meters away.

A co-op game where I actually don't mind randoms joining me! What is this madness?!
Seriously though, the humour is great, the music is glorious and if you have friends to play with it only gets better. Much fun, even when things are going to hell in a handbasket.

It's a satirical homage to all your favorite Sci-Fi universes and it's got fun, strategic gameplay with three other players alongside you. The progression system is also one of my personal favorites as you don't need to pay much of anything to unlock the cool stuff. I didn't spend a dime.

The game's server issues have received a lot of service. As of now, I believe the devs have stated the servers can now support somewhere in the ballpark of 700,000 people. Now, if you are afraid of not being able to play the game still then absolutely wait to purchase the game. But I have not had any server problems in the past week or so of playing. 

This game is very good. I'd argue it is better than a lot of the mainstream triple A games. It doesn't have 4K cut scenes everywhere, or a bunch of pseudo-choices for you to make like a lot of mainline games these days, but it has something a lot of other games seemingly forget to include. *FUN*. The game is very fun, and baring a few glitches here and there, I haven't had many issues with it. The glitches I did experience are honestly ones I see in games that charge you 80 dollars out the gate anyway, and the devs had their priorities set on server issues rather than bugfixing, so I expect now that the servers are better that they'll focus more on glitch fixing.

There are microtransactions in this game, which may turn people off. But so far I haven't found anything that you couldn't get by just playing the game normally. I am a tad concerned about there being only four items at a time in the shop, however, as that may prove problematic if they add new content to the store, where stuff you want may take forever to cycle back into the shop.

There are a few balancing issues, certain weapons and stratagems are simply leagues ahead of the other options, you'll find on the higher difficulties people all start gravitating towards the same options. So, I do hope the devs buff some of the other weapons or offer options to upgrade them to become better.

Really, those are the only real downsides I have with the game. It is genuinely fun. And can be really challenging at times. You can really cater your playstyle quite easily. If you want some relaxing fun just mowing down hordes of enemies, Trivial and Easy difficulty are perfect for that. If you want some decent challenge and situations where you have to think on the fly or die- then medium challenging and hard are quite good for that too. If you want to (suffer)/challenge yourself and put your skills to the test, there are the other difficulties after that.

And die a lot you will. A little titbit for anyone buying this game- it isn't meant to be a game you go flawless through a mission. If you do- that's great! But a lot of the times, you won't, especially if you go on higher difficulties. And that's okay. If someone accidentally kills you because a bug kicked their grenade back towards the frontlines, that's fine. If you accidentally forget you have your grenade launcher equipped and not your assault rifle and decide the front door of that building looked better with your freedom blood all over it- that's fine too. Get suddenly jump scared by an invisible enemy because you were trying to help your friend not get trampled by a charging super-sized bug? That's fine too, it happens. That's why you have so many lives. It is much more fun to play this game when you let go of any perceived need to have perfect runs. The worst that happens is you drop your special weapon and samples, but any good teammate will pick your samples and drop you close enough to collect your weapon. (Assuming it is safe to drop you there)
(Loot is all shared, no need to worry about things getting 'stolen')

The game has a lot to offer, I strongly recommend it to anyone who likes horde shooters or any fans of Starship Troopers. And if you're curious, I suggest buying it and playing it for an hour and a half. You could always refund it if you didn't enjoy it, but I think an hour and a half is plenty of time to figure out if you like this game or not.

(PS. Last word of advice, when going through training, don't be like me and forget to let go of your sprint button when dolphin diving, or the auto turrets will ensure your record on the wall of martyr's looks rather awkward indeed)

This game is over hyped. Matchmaking errors, mid-match disconnects, bugs, exploits, lower level players queuing for hard+ difficulties. At some point we can't keep falling back on excuses like "it's a small dev team" or "be patient, the developers didn't expect this game to be so popular." After 2 weeks of daily errors, Helldivers 2 seemingly have stable servers. 

2/23/24 Edit: I was kicked from numerous games today either mid-match or at extraction. If I had more invested in HD2 I might have been irritated, but this behavior is pathetic. Pathetic that players are removing people from the game, and pathetic the developers are enabling this immature conduct. "Host your own game." Sure, if I host I won't be kicked, but then my lobbies constantly fill with lower level players. It's a lose-lose situation. I'm not a stickler for meta loadouts. There are some good early stratagems available to everyone, but I'm just not all that interested in using 5+ reinforcement stratagems in the first 5 minutes because our level 7 can't avoid or damage the Charger. 

Although the gameplay is enticing, I’ve encountered some challenges/issues that have negatively impacted my gameplay experience.

1. Progression. The XP leveling system was very slow before they added bonus gains. Players collect warbonds and samples during missions to upgrade ship modules and unlock more available stratagems. Ship module upgrades are heavily priced between 60-100 common samples per upgrade, with higher upgrade tiers requiring rarer samples. 

2. No weapon leveling/customization. When you unlock a new weapon there is no further customization you can do to further improve that weapon. You can’t change magazine size, ammunition type, stock…nothing. However, you can choose various optical scopes, firing rate, and a flashlight option (which is completely useless even in these dark wastelands) after loading into a mission. 

3. No saved loadouts. You manually select which stratagems you intend to use each and every mission.

4. Mobility. Aside from lunging, sliding, running, and the jetpack, player mobility in HD2 is atrocious. This doesn’t even include all of the environmental hazards, enemy collision, or obstacles to slow or impede player movement. 

5. Enemies are bullet sponges. Most Chargers take between 1-2 Recoilless rockets or several unsafe railgun shots. These support stratagems ultimately require two players unless you want to kneel for 10 seconds to load 1 round and completely expose yourself. I’ve found Bile Titans to be a nuisance. it’s that one unlucky player who has to aggro the boss while everyone tries to strategically time their stratagem strikes to land directly on it. Every YT video out there is the martyr who nuked themselves along with the boss.

6. Matchmaking. “Failed to join game lobby.” This game is scaled for 4 players, so leave your matchmaking open unless you’re a team of 4 players. Other posts have mentioned griefers and being kicked mid-way through missions. I've been kicked prior to extraction and disconnected from network errors multiple times. I have also witnessed another player repeatedly team kill another until they left the mission. Just like all online games, disconnects are expected, but giving hosts full power to remove someone without reason - causing the kicked player to lose everything is baffling. Samples, XP, and currency should be awarded in-game when completing objectives, not after extracting. 

7. Bugs. There haven't been too many bugs as of the recent patches aside from getting stuck in the terrain. The cryopod bug has to be the most irritating bug for me. If you load into an open mission at the same time as another, you will be locked from entering the ship and remain in the cryopod loading area. You must wait for the host to enter the launch pod to being the mission, otherwise you’re stuck. 

8. Samples. Either I'm matching with players who haven't figured out how expensive ship module costs are, or the developers didn't stress the importance of collecting samples enough in the tutorial. At my current difficulty there are usually about 45 available common and rare samples combined, but our team never extracts with more than 15 samples. This warrants a crucial change: 1. Increase the number of samples in each pick up, ex. 3-5 samples per icon, or 2. Reduce the number of samples required per upgrade. 

9. Replayability. The gameplay loop is monotonous - Launch one of the 10 or so missions, destroy enemies and complete secondary objectives, find hidden samples/medals/credits, and extract. Aside from a community event and a daily mission, I don't see much of a grind aside from the battlepass, unlocking stratagems, and improving your ship. There is no player progression/proficiency, weapon tracking, or bounty system (aside from the daily objective). 

Negativity aside, the explosions are phenomenal and the weapons feel fantastic. They have a certain weight to them. I want to do so much more than just eliminate my enemies and collect weird mushrooms and ores. I want additional currencies and materials to grind for crafting and/or upgrading. I'd like to see weapons or armor with set bonuses that are earned through player achievement, not just cosmetics gained using super credits. What if enemies themselves dropped resources or materials that we might utilize to further our ship development? Maybe instead of carrying everything to the main extraction, could we unlock smaller extraction pods designed for mid-mission resource extraction? 

Helldivers 2 feels like something teetering between a Destiny Vanguard Strike and a Raid. Every objective can be solved by annihilating your foes or by making use of the D-pad. It's not a horrible experience, but it doesn't deserve the overwhelming praise it's currently receiving.

Game's a lot of fun and the developers have actively been working to fix server issues, which they seem to have now. Appreciate the open communication from them as they've been working on sorting out the issues from launch. Wish we got more games like this, it's a return to what games used to be about, just having fun. Can't deny the $40 price tag is a little high for what's here but given how enjoyable the experience has been I don't mind. A bit of the modern monetization is here with battle pass progression but unlike the usual ones you can't pay to progress it and while there's a premium track you can very easy unlock it without ever paying a cent. Game does need some mixing up in terms of the sandbox since after a certain difficulty level there's a clear loadout you should be running, not because it's the best one but because it's simply the only one that's viable; hoping the developers can work on that in the future because it's fun getting to experiment with loadouts but you have to stay in the lower difficulties if you want to do so.

Recommend getting this with a group of friends, while there is online matchmaking and there are a number of good players you've got a good chance of getting matched with somebody that kills more teammates than enemies with airstrikes or a hacker that trivializes the whole game and takes the fun out of it.

It's great. Performance never dipped much for me at all. Gameplay and graphics are fantastic. The missions are much more involved than they were in the first game, which is cool. The challenge is real. Sound design is really spot on with the guns and explosions. Grind isn't all that bad, and missions are fun to complete over and over again with significant variation in objective type.

As for *my* main critiques, some of the stratagems and most of the weapons feel a bit weak. There's definitely a clear meta loadout for missions at difficulty 8 and 9. I really hope the game sees a balance pass to bring the primaries close to the usefulness of the Breaker shotgun, as well as some tweaking stratagems for higher difficulty use.

Overall, it's an easy 9/10 from me. Loads of fun with friends, so bring them with you.

I changed my review to a thumbs-up. The game is in a much better state now. They implemented an AFK auto-kick system that kicks players after 15 mins of inactivity. This is something the playerbase requested since there were players who refused to log out for days because they did not want to be stuck in the login queue. It wasn’t even a real queue system, it just tries to log you in every 30 or so seconds and whoever is lucky gets in which was worse. They also increased the concurrent users cap to 700,000. With these much needed changes and improvements we no longer have to sit at the title screen waiting for an open spot to get in the game. It’s instantaneous now. The rewards bug is fixed. Quickplay is also fixed.

Love this game, its an absolute gem and its the most fun i've had in a while, most often if you play with a squad. However aside from some server issues that we all know about, there are a few issues that I am unable to write off or dismiss:
Your helldiver:
Stims: 
I don't know if people have it rigged a certain way, but no matter what bind I have my stim or reload on, when I REALLY need it, it seems to not register at the WORST times, but i'll see uploads of people actively getting shot or beaten in a mosh pit of bugs and stimming, how?
The Pod: 
Does not steer at times, others I can steer it a bit but other times it just refuses to alter direction at all even a little bit.
Weapons: 
In particular the upgraded variant of your initial assault rifle, which states "Medium armor penetration" DOES NOT penetrate medium armor and seems to be sabotaged by the reduced damage stat.
The Railgun has safe and unsafe mode but the only difference is unsafe causes the weapon to explode in your hand, but no power difference if you manage to fire before it explodes.
The Spear should prioritize the largest target in its crosshairs, so many times I or my compatriots have tried to fire on a bile titan only for it to somehow lock onto a nearby Rusher, which was not the intended target
Movement: 
Will vault when I am sprinting over reasonable obstacles, however seems to struggle on some inclines that are basically 2 steps on a staircase. In addition sometimes when diving will refuse to get up unless dive key is hit again, but will sometimes remember sprint input and stand up from prone to run as ordered.
Strategems:
The Railcannon strike will sometimes deviate from "target the largest enemy closest to the beacon" and pick a target at random despite there being something like a tank or hulk near it, it will target a chainsaw mech instead

Now for enemies
Automatons:
Cannon Turret texture will sometimes show a destroyed turret until you get blasted from behind. Dropping a 500KG AND a carpet bomb at times does not destroy it either.
Rocket Troopers are locked on to you regardless of difficulty whether Easy or Helldive, they will snipe you with a rocket mid-dive or will break off from squad and hide on their own, waiting until after firefights to fire at you.
Reinforcement rate is somewhat broken starting at challenging, 1 flare seems to summon at least 6 dropships that will clip into each other and drop a whole ton of bots on one spot.
Hulks are somehow able, despite weighing possibly hundreds of tons, able to keep pace with you while running without stamina and with stamina, still manage to gain on you little by little, how?

Terminids
Honestly my only gripe is the rusher and bile titan
Rusher can spawn in groups of 4 on challenging and higher and seem to go over obstacles that they should headbutt into and stop for a moment. They're also capable of hairpin turns, which with their size should either be impossible or break their legs. When blasting with a recoiless rifle, they will slide forward a great distance, ending up right next to you or just behind you somehow.
The Bile Titan has very little pause with its vomit attack and spams it relentlessly and with incredible range that slightly sweeps after its intended target

Having said ALL of that, I do love this game and I really hope they iron out everything they need to, i'm still playing and doing my part.

As of now (Feb 15~16), the game is half playable. Match making got significantly better yet still hard to connect lot of times. My main problem is that game crashes or server disconnects mid session. Today, I played about 5 sessions and none made to the end because of those problems and also due to a bug that does not get me back into the game with reinforcement beacon, I had this about total of 5 times, where other players are revived but I stay dead even though reinforcement count is remained. I probably wasted about total of 10 hours because most of these problems happened late in sessions.

It is pain even though I own the game, I can't progress on events and daily missions because it's only half playable, I know devs are working hard to fix these issues but I doubt I will get compensation for this. I will likely stop playing until actual patches come up and the game is stable enough. I'm pretty unhappy about the loss of progress over this, I recommend people to wait for a month or so.

This game scratches the exact same itch for me as Deep Rock Galactic. Run and gun with fun buds. Die a lot. Kill a lot. Have a LOT of fun. If this game keeps a steady player base, I can see a lot of fun campaigns coming out through the use of the huge galactic map. LOTS of planets to defend, LOTS of 'bots and bugs to kill.

The devs already plan to add mechs to the game "post-launch" so that's exciting. More stratagems is absolutely going to be a way to keep people entertained, so I hope to see more with time. They also should absolutely double down on the fashion-game as well. That's gonna sell a lot, and with some REASONABLY priced micro-transactions, they can probably keep a lot of players happy with cool armor sets.

That beings said, we always need more bodies for the grinder so an Xbox port would be a very consumer friendly thing to happen. That being said, it's wild Sony even put this on PC at launch lmfao. So we'll see.

I had a negative experience with this game and have refunded it. I am considering purchasing it again as I have heard positive things from friends. 

It had somewhat disastrous of an experience;

1. The game conflicts with bluetooth headphones, launching the game muted all audio outside the game. It seems the issue is with bluetooth headphones that have headset feature. 
2. I have a mid to high end PC, but the game appears to be so poorly optimized that even at medium settings I was only getting 65-80 FPS, and this doesn't seem to be warranted as the game doesn't even appear very high fidelity. In other intensive games, like Cyberpunk (an extreme example) I get 90-100 frames. In Assassin's creed Odyssey I get 150 FPS on average. Optimization seems to be a big issue.
3. The animations are extremely clunky and feel cheap, when moving and turning the animations skip around and the player appears to "float" on the ground at times.
4. The game completely froze my PC twice, within a short period of time, maybe 30 mins while I was messing around with settings trying to get better FPS. This is pretty sad considering the specs I have and the hype for this game.
5. For the first 20 minutes I was trying to play the game the servers were full. How can this be for such a highly marketed game? Maybe use some of your insane marketing budget to actually operate a sufficient number of servers...

All in all bad experience, not necessarily related to gameplay, but from a tech standpoint the game was a let down. Hopefully it gets better with patches, I may give it another go if the crashing and optimization get better.

The game is finally in a state where crashes are pretty rare, and server stability seems to have settled. This game is an absolute blast, simply put - I can safely recommend it in its current state.

I will say, right now the scientist evacuation missions are still way too hard, and hunt missions (kill x bugs/automatons) are far too easy. Mission balance has improved from patch to patch.

Excellent game, constant updates, and you can finally log in without hassle. Server capacity has been increased and I suspect it might fill up again, but shouldn't be anywhere near as bad.

I can recommend you give the game a try. It's not going to be a game for everyone. It's a difficult game which mostly requires you to learn and get better to progress to higher difficulties. As you level you will unlock tools that might make the journey easier, but there are a few unlocked at level 20 which are game changing. 

The game is definitely meant to be played at the hardest difficulties. Don't be scared to bump up the difficulty, you will have a blast even if you get completely destroyed. It's all about the feeling of being wildly outnumbered, running and shooting for your life.

Helldivers 2 is by far the best game I've played when it comes to coop/crossplay. I love the fact that friendly fire cannot be turned off, adding a thrilling element of strategy. The landing music sets the perfect tone for each mission, which is always competitive and keeps us on the edge of our seats. Most importantly, it's an absolute blast to play with friends. The armor sets are visually stunning, and I enjoy switching them up for each mission. However, I feel the guns could use some improvement, as they all seem to perform similarly. I hope to see more stratagems added and more weapon and armor options. Overall, I commend the makers of Helldivers 2 for creating such an incredible experience.

I have no idea how you get a company like Sony to publish this and the servers are this bad those guys have like unlimited money. I completely understand them not expecting the volume of players on a sequel to what is by comparison a dead game, but for the issues to still persist to this degree after the amount of time it has been out is just bonkers. They also somehow launched this game without an AFK timer so people until recently were just able to sit in the game AFK which would exacerbate the problem of not being able to play the game. Not that anyone cares, but I'll obviously change this review when and if they fix these issues but at the moment I'd say wait or buy something else.

TL;DR:  At the core we have a fantastic game, but the server problems, the lack of proofing to do anything about these server problems, as well as the publisher kind of makes the entire experience bad.
10/10 Democracy Simulator
loved the game, but the server is so bad!!!! I had waited for hours just to get in.. and another bugs after bugs!!

Okay, the devs have been getting slammed in the reviews for their server issues, and rightly so. But, they are working through them, and now the game is actually playable, with only the occasional bug (pun not intended).

Right up top, I want to mention the monetization. The game has a battle pass, a rotating store, and microtransactions for in-game currency. The return on what you can get for your dollars is not very good, but not nearly as bad as I've seen in other games. Ten bucks will get you the battle pass, or a couple good armors from the store, which can actually be very helpful. To its credit, they do give you some premium currency as you progress through the levels, and you can earn a potentially infinite amount of it from in-game tasks; you can actually get by without needing to spend any extra money, at all, with minimal grinding. Really, the microtransactions feel extremely unnecessary, and are actually not that predatory. Still, I would much rather the game just NOT have them. I have a bad taste in my mouth for any game that uses a fucking battle pass, and even if this game is a not-that-bad implementation of one, it still has one, and it's worse off for it. I'd much rather they just charge more up front, or a flat fee for a DLC, than manipulative bullshit like they and every other game nowadays have.

Getting into the gameplay, server issues aside, the game is actually a ton of fun. One note, DO NOT expect to play this game solo. It is not at all balanced for single- or even duo-play. It's at its best when you've got a full squad of 4, and it does not do much to tweak the balance down if you've got less than that. But, if you can get a group together, or don't mind playing with randos, it can be a legit great time. 

There's not many games out there that can give you the same feeling of being hopelessly outnumbered, but also of having the firepower to fight your way through it. The impacts and explosions are visceral and a lot of work was put into making them PUNCH with each orbital strike or nuclear impact. The deaths (most of the time) feel like they're your fault, rather than the game being cheesy and unfair. There's a good amount of depth to the mechanics, and there's enough variety to keep you playing for a good while.

There are some things that feel like they're misbalanced, but it's hard to tell if they're intentional because the options you start with are cheap and shitty, or if they just have a few things that need to be nerfed. In particular, once you get the Autocannon at level 10, you can pretty much kill anything. It's a shame, though, since there are a pretty spicy selection of weapons available, but most of them simply do not live up to the same standard, and are not worth taking. Why take a heavy sniper when the autocannon can do all the same stuff, better, for longer?

There are currently two factions, the bugs depicted on all the marketing, and the Automatons. Both factions play extremely differently, and jumping back and forth is almost like playing a different game; a very nice balance for more variety. That said, each faction has only a handful of mission types that you will do with them. Blow up a bug nest, then extract. Help survivors load up into an escape pod while defending them from robots, then extract. Blow up some bug eggs, and a bunch of nests, then extract. It's all enough to keep you playing for a while, but already things can start to feel same-y, only ~20 hours in.

Oh, and one last thing I'll note, the game is AWFUL at tutorializing. There have been multiple times I've dropped into a new mission type, and stood around for 10 minutes not knowing how to progress the mission. The game does not give you very clear instructions on some objectives, and unless you know what you're supposed to do, it can be fucking frustrating to sit there with no progress while getting hammered by wave after wave of enemies. And even when you do know what you need to do, if you're not on voice with your squad, some objectives can be absolutely frustrating to coordinate.

All in all, a very solid, fun game. If it didn't have microtransactions and a damn battle pass, it would be one of my new favorites, but alas, at least it's one of the less frustratingly-monetized games to come out in a long time. If you've got some friends, pick it up, and have some fun (and try not to kill each other!).

Let's put those doubters on mute for a sec and dive into why this game is off-the-charts awesome. I'm talking about non-stop co-op excitement that's been missing from the gaming scene for ages. Arrowhead Game Studios? Yeah, they've outdone themselves with this sparkling gem. Okay, okay, so there were a few hiccups with the servers in the beginning, but come on, that's ancient history now. This game? It's like a shining beacon of gaming brilliance. And get this—you don't have to buddy up if you're not feeling it. Going solo is a whole other ball game, and let me tell you, it's a thrill ride.

Now, am I singing the praises of these devs? You bet I am. If you're reading this, do yourself a solid and check out some gameplay vids. Trust me, you'll be itching to jump in yourself. And when you do, don't hesitate to grab a copy because this is one ride you won't want to miss. Get ready to immerse yourself in heart-pounding adventures that'll make you feel like you're smack dab in the middle of Starship Troopers and Terminator, all rolled into one.

So, what's the holdup, Helldiver? Super Earth's calling, and it needs heroes like you—stat! Suit up, lock and load, and get ready to unleash some serious whoop-ass on those alien invaders. The fate of the Super Earth is in your hands, Helldiver!

Honestly this feels like what every Triple A Live service game SHOULD feel like. 

- Reasonably priced
- Amazing Co-op experience
- Replayability is high thanks to random generated missions. 
- Gameplay from guns to Stratagems all feels beautiful. 
- Despite the lack of servers they suffered from for a while. Actual connection to said severs is good enough that playing internationally doesn't seem to cause that much of a hindrance. So great for the OCE base connecting to places like America

And the Live Service? This is one of the very select few games I am entirely okay with it.
- You can find premium currency in missions just by exploring
- There is Free Passes that reward some pretty dope items as well as more Premium currency.
- The Medals to unlock things are easy to both find and earn. 
- BATTLE PASSES DO NOT EXPIRE - No FoMo. 

If you want a Co-op shooter that you can grind for hours on end with both friends and randoms alike, this is definitely the title. Devs have done great in what they've put out. And deserve every bit of positive attention the game is getting.

As someone who 100% HD1, HD2 is felt like a skinwalker was just wearing my favorite game of all time. The perspective change, changes everything. In short, it makes games less cooperative compared to the last game. Even if you fix the server and optimization, there are a lot of questionable things that make me wonder "Do they even play their own game?"

 Good thing:
- Punchy weapons
- Cool Music
- Pretty landscape

Bad:
- With third person perspective, they seem to want emphasize more on each individual helldivers. There are now injuries, health packs, to help your helldiver survive longer. But it's not long enough that most enemies can instakill you. Back in HD1, reinforcement were infinite, the only thing stopping is the cooldown. Now, they are limited, but they still didn't balance thing toward it. Aka, your health is really low.
- Enemies spawn are unbalanced and it feels like they designed it with a top down perspective in mind. Now that 80% of borgs and 70% of bugs have armor, the game wants you to shoot at weakpoint of the enemies. But it's impossible with how little they are and how flinchy you are when shot, and also the fact that there are 3000 enemies behind you. The bots are much worse compared to the bugs, since their headshot hitbox is just so tiny.
- Resupply is now shared, but to compensate they want you to explore the maps to find more. It's an okay incentives, but there should be at least two resup with how people in this game like to play solo...
- Now that the camera isn't tethered, the most efficient way is to actually split up. That and to grind for the super credit. For those who say that the grind is "Not that bad", it is not true. The grind is super slow, both normal progression and super credit
- Even normal progression felt really slow compared to HD1, everything takes around 3-5x longer. The super credit one (for those who plan to play the full content with just the base) are rng. You will first need to find a point of interest, hope that point of interest spawn super credit instead of: medals, weapons, ammo, samples. So not only you need to hope you find that point of interest, you need to hope that it spawns super credit. Oh and you only get around 20 SC per spot, each mission at most might have 3 (higher diff seems to be more likely). So yeah, I expect around 30-40 hours of grind to unlock the next warbond for free. 
- Balancing is all over the place, they didnt learn from HD1 at all. 95% of lodout is useless in higher difficulty, everyone only wants to play railgun. It's boring and not fun.
- Patrols are indistinguishable  compared to normal enemies
- Your radar is weak, so you will get caught by something
- Very bad optimization, low setting is impossible to play

It's sad, because I bet arrowhead is not going to make another top down after the success of this.

To be fair, you have to have a very high IQ to understand HELLDIVERS 2. The humour is extremely subtle, and without a solid grasp of theoretical physics most of the jokes will go over a typical viewer's head. There's also HELLDIVER 2'S nihilistic outlook, which is deftly woven into his characterisation- his personal philosophy draws heavily from Narodnaya Volya literature, for instance. The fans understand this stuff; they have the intellectual capacity to truly appreciate the depths of these jokes, to realise that they're not just funny- they say something deep about LIFE. As a consequence people who dislike HELLDIVERS 2 truly ARE idiots- of course they wouldn't appreciate, for instance, the humour in HELLDIVERS 2's existential catchphrase "HELLDIVERS 2," which itself is a cryptic reference to Turgenev's Russian epic Fathers and Sons. I'm smirking right now just imagining one of those addlepated simpletons scratching their heads in confusion as Duck Duck Zeus's genius wit unfolds itself on their computer screens. What fools.. how I pity them. 😂

And yes, by the way, i DO have a HELLDIVERS 2 tattoo. And no, you cannot see it. It's for the ladies' eyes only- and even then they have to demonstrate that they're within 5 IQ points of my own (preferably lower) beforehand. Nothin personnel kid 😎

Should you buy this game? To answer that, ask yourself a question.

 "Am I just an ordinary citizen, or am I a defender of freedom?"

 You are the last line of defense against the cosmic forces that threaten our great world and the principles of democracy. You're not just fighting Termanids and Automatons; you're fighting for the very essence of what makes Super Earth, Super Earth.

In the vast expanse of the cosmos, you are the beacon of liberty, the embodiment of courage. When those communist bugs and socialist robots look up at the stars, they tremble because they know that the spirit of freedom burns brighter than any supernova. You carry the torch of justice, and you're here to remind them that Super Earth's spirit is unyielding, unbreakable. 

So lock and load, Helldiver. March into the cosmic battleground, and let the stars witness the resilience of a nation that fights not just for itself but for the freedom of all. You are the embodiment of Super America, and you will triumph because the heart of democracy beats within you!
MY LIFE FOR SUPER EARTH

Helldivers 2 has completely deviated from the original Helldivers with a 3rd person perspective. This iteration of Helldivers is still engaging when it works but you'll notice some performance issues here or there. With that being said, many players have experienced several issues that continue to persist.

Issues:
1) Game Guard failed to connect (I've had to attempt to launch the game a couple of times before I have a successful connection)
2) Black screen. In the instance that Game Guard does connect, sometimes a black screen is met with no audio. There doesn't seem to be a consistent solution to this issue that occurs and we'll likely have to wait for a patch to fix it.
3) Random crashes (This just occurred a few minutes before I started typing up this review. I was in a group of four and loading into a mission but the game crashed and I was prompted to write an error report to PlayStation Studios)

Conclusion:
The game is fun when it does work but at its current state, it's best to let Arrowhead continue patching up the issues that keep hindering this game. I am puzzled as to how much testing was conducted prior to the launch as the issues that occurred at launch has had some patches.

I purchased the game and requested a refund after the first two mentioned issues just prevented me from playing the game back on Feb 20th. But after I saw some patch notes stating fixes to Game Guard connection and the Black screen, I decided to trust Arrowhead and re-purchase the game again and try it out. Hopefully, Arrowhead gets things resolved and we'll get a consistent and functioning game. But with things as they are now for the game, understand that the game is buggy and will be buggy until things are patched up.

Hopefully six months from now things will be stable and by then you'll catch the game on the summer sale.
