Edit post pop-cap increase update ~2024-02-22: I can actually play the game, now! Yay! And I find that the entire game is absolute trash. Tried my hand at a Trivial (easiest) difficulty mission against Automatons (because no one plays them, apparently, so you get missions to play them). I got absolutely swarmed and wrecked. The entire balance team needs to be replaced - the spawn rate for these cyborgs MUST be reduced by at LEAST 50%. Then I jumped into some Easy difficulty bug missions, had some fun running around finding stuff and killing bugs, but eventually would find myself surrounded or jumped on. Goddam bugs keep spawning right behind you, where there is absolutely no reason for them to be, when you're being rushed from the front. In that mound of frustration, I hit against the primary issue with this game (when you can actually play it, that is): the controls and responsiveness of the game is absolute trash. You can't smoothly move from target to target, trying to switch between weapons can animation-lock you into reloading something you didn't know was empty, the character movement is WAY too slow to avoid attacks, everything is clunky as all hell! The only advice I can give is make absolutely sure you're prepared for an attack before you get attacked, and be ready to die a LOT and lose missions (and all your progress for the past half hour) because you died too much. 

Now, maybe my problems arise from using a controller instead of mouse and keyboard. Maybe my problems arise from not having a high enough rank to have all the fancy toys and whatnot unlocked (which shows that whatever team handles balancing equipment vs enemies needs to be fired, because you shouldn't have to play the game to be able to play the game). Maybe I'm just bad. No mater what the reason is, I'm heavily frustrated by a GAME I'm playing to RELAX. I hate this game. Don't buy in unless you want frustration for no good goddam reason. 

Initial review, pre-pop-cap increase update: First time I launched the game, had a black screen for about 20 mintues, then finally saw some PSA BS, then watched a loading page for about 30 minutes of constantly saying the server was full. Gave up, restarted, relaunched, waited another 30-ish minutes, finally got in. And then the tutorial was bugged, and I couldn't low crawl through the first obstacle, despite being full-prone. Actually got stuck on the obstacle after about 3 minutes of trying everything, and resorted to the Return to Ship option, which meant I wouldn't be able to run the tutorial, but what the heck, I had friends lucky enough to get experience and could walk me through stuff. And then the game crashes when I try and access a mission on the map. An hour wasted, to crash on trying to launch a mission. 

Wait 1-3 months, and try it then. Maybe they'll have the bugs and server capacity issues fixed. Looks like a bomb game, just too bad I can't play it.

Error. Login limit reached. 

Attention, brave citizens of SUPER EARTH. It's time to question the safety of your family and wonder why you haven't enlisted sooner!

 HELLDIVERS 2, a rollercoaster of bug-bot-squashing patriotism.

Due to some login limit shenanigans. The first week was like trying to infiltrate a bug-hole without a grenade . But fear not, because once you breach the black screens and ‘Error. Login limit reached.’, you're in for a wild ride of SUPER proportions. Bugs and glitches might get you down (looking at you, disappearing super samples), but remember, a true HELLDIVER fights through these hiccups!

For the modest fee of $40 and the occasional in-team shouting match, you can proudly join the ranks of those fighting for FREEDOM, DEMOCRACY and LIBERTY. Because nothing says love for your family like enlisting to protect them from extraterrestrial threats.

Starting in HELLDIVERS 2 is like being thrown into the deep end of a pool filled with giant bugs and walking toasters armed with rocket launchers. The tutorial mission? More like a crash course in ‘good enough.’ With a 22% combat effectiveness upon enlistment, you'll quickly find out that survival isn't guaranteed, but it sure is hilarious.

Prepare to face swarms of insect-like creatures where even the tiniest ones pack a punch that could make truck-kun jealous. And don't get me started on the legions of death robots with a knack for rocket accuracy.

Teaming up with fellow warriors is surprisingly smooth. Within moments, you'll be shoulder-to-shoulder with other confused recruits, forming trauma bonds that can only be forged in the fires of interstellar warfare. Sure, there's the occasional Guard Dog Rover that might mistake you for the enemy or an orbital barrage tossed WAAAAY too close, but what's a little friendly fire between super earth's finest?

The universe map changes with the flow of the entire playerbase, when you win, you liberate, when you lose.. Well hopefully your family won't blame you too much. Venturing into higher difficulties is like a mental marathon relying on nothing but you and your teams strategic brilliance.. or blind screaming. The sense of accomplishment when you emerge victorious is enough to make you sing the national anthem with tears in your eyes.

Even after unlocking all the gear and stratagems it won't satiate your hunger for justice; it'll only intensify your desire to dive back into the fray.

HELLDIVERS 2 scratches that itch from back when online games were simple, run-shoot, run-scream, run-away!  it's a nostalgic journey into the chaos of camaraderie and explosive patriotism. Enlist today, because the universe needs a hero, and that hero is you!

Overall I certainly recommend this game to other players!

There are a lot of negative reviews on this platform, so let me just start by addressing some of them. In doing so I'll communicate why exactly I recommend the game in spite of its early issues.

1. The complaints in a lot of the negative reviews are a bit overblown, to be honest. The first complaint is (naturally) smoothness and how the game runs. The game is a little beefy and guzzles resources sometimes, but on relatively modern hardware it is completely manageable 99.99% of the time with small frame stutters every now and again, and that's when I push my computer to the limit by cranking up all of the settings and playing one of the free-roam missions that spawn large hordes at long distances. On medium or high settings, most gaming rigs should be able to run this just fine with limited or no issues. 

However, AMD GPUs (7000 series in particular) can have some trouble running the game and this can be a problem for AMD users. Contrary to the beliefs some negative reviewers, this is the result of an AMD issue, NOT of a Helldivers issue. AMD has released an update for their GPUs which has fixed the problem for most players. Even still, the Helldivers developers have communicated that they are testing on AMD hardware just to make sure. Some have complained about AMD processors as well. As an AMD CPU user, I can say that I have experienced zero issues running the game smoothly when using settings appropriate for my computer's capabilities.

2. The second issue I see in the negative reviews is server issues and trouble getting into matches. The issues surrounding getting logged in have almost entirely been fixed, so people experiencing issues getting into the game in the first place are most likely experiencing issues on their end of the equation. Even if they aren't, on the rare case I've received an error, I have gotten in on my second try. This has only happened to me once since the server issues were patched a few days ago.

It's also true that getting into a matchmaking match can sometimes return a "failed to join" message. However, this is an issue that takes about two seconds to fix. The reason it happens is because you are attempting to join a match at the same time as other people who have clicked on the same match as you. There are a lot of people playing the game and most of them don't want to host their own lobbies, so there are more people joining than hosting and that means all you have to do to fix the problem most of the time is select another match. 

Every time I've had the issue it has taken all of five seconds to get into a match afterwards. Hosting a match has some similar issues in that people might not join on your game immediately after you throw your SOS beacon or open up your lobby to the public. This is because there is a natural buffer of about a minute or two between tossing your beacon and your game appearing on the world map. On top of that buffer, you are competing with a lot of other matches for players who might not be interested in joining a single person in an in-progress match. If you want people to join your game, select a mission and wait about 1-2 minutes in your destroyer and your lobby will fill almost immediately after it hits the world map.

3. The third issue I've heard about in other reviews is that the controls are clunky. This criticism strikes me primarily as an issue of not understanding the control scheme of the game rather than an issue with the control scheme itself. Your character's weapon will fire its rounds directly from the front of your barrel (barrel-point aiming) and those rounds will take a small amount of time to travel. This means you'll have to make sure your barrel is lined up before you fire or else you'll miss or graze your target instead of getting a solid, clean hit. I'm not typically one who goes crazy about "realism" in games, so I'll leave that out of the discussion and instead say that this mechanic makes shooting very satisfying once you get the hang of using the true crosshair, and lends some necessary weight and punch to the process of aiming and shooting. The gunplay is fantastic after you get used to barrel-point aiming, and the ability to know where your weapon will shoot at all times is actually rather helpful.

Other control issues include movement and inputs "not working." What I believe is happening for those players is that they are being hit by an enemy while attempting to use a stim (healing item), reload, prime a grenade, et cetera. You will be in constant contact with enemy units that will harass you from the time you land to the time you extract. When those enemies hit you, your character's action will be interrupted and you will have some damage recoil applied to your aim. That means that you may have to restart the process of reloading or stimming, and if you're frightened or overwhelmed by what's happening in front of you you might not notice that your character's arm/leg animations stopped playing when you got hit. You might not even register that you got hit in the first place. That means you will have to get VERY used to registering when you take damage and you will have to develop the skill to react to that damage appropriately. After the first couple of hours of gameplay, the feeling that "inputs aren't working" goes away entirely because you learn how to time things correctly. It's just like any other challenging game mechanic.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

Now that I've gone over some of the issues above and why they aren't extreme enough to give this game a negative review in my opinion, let's talk about a couple of positives.

1. The game's play-cycle is addictive and just arcade enough to be massive fun. The premise is so ridiculous and the gameplay so serious that it's almost comical how into your role you can get while you're being assaulted by about a thousand bugs/automatons at once. You land, secure critical objectives, destroy enemy outposts, and then fight your way to extraction where you have a final standoff with whichever enemy you're fighting before taking off in a VTOL that shoots 20mm rounds from its nose turret. The entire time, you're legging it through combat with hordes of your chosen enemy variety and managing your ammunition and healing items, and sometimes those of your partner/group as well. This makes surviving from the beginning to the end of a mission challenging, but dying isn't annoying because you have an allowance of respawns that makes sure you aren't stuck watching your squad struggle with one person less than normal just because you made an oopsie. In some missions, the amount of respawns you have will seem generous. In others, it will seem like it's just short of enough. If you pay attention for the first couple of hours of gameplay, you won't ever experience a situation where the number of respawns makes the mission feel impossible. It's all about balancing resources and avoiding taking (too much) damage until the right time.

2. The community is one of the smarter ones I've seen in a cooperative game. After the first 10 level ups, you can assume that a player has a *decent* idea of what to do when they drop into your game (or you drop into theirs), and at around that time you'll notice that most players will start dropping intelligent markers on the map that suggest where to go next, sharing supplies with one another, picking weapons and support equipment that complements other teammates' gear, doing friendly emotes in the lobbies, and in general being good models for online player behavior. I have dropped into a couple of games where players ran off and got themselves killed at the squad's expense or teamkilled one another by accident far too often, but these are the exception.

These two things are qualities that Helldivers 2 has uniquely made its own. Just the two of them make the game worth it. Just pick up the base version of the game and try it out!

This is a gem of a Player Verses Environment cooperative game! I certainly recommend this if you enjoy the genre. You can play solo but it's a tough deal and easy to get overrun by the enemy. 

This game HAD a rough start, mainly from being so popular, but the Developers have been on top of the ball since the beginning with patching, working around the clock, and communicating to the community with it showing positive results.

NOW this game has made it super easy to team up and find others. Servers have been smooth and matchmaking has been working wonderfully fast for me since the recent patches. No wait times. No hang ups. Just finding other Helldivers that want to send out a "hot cup of liber-tea!"

There are micro-transactions in the game but EVERYTHING can be earned in the matches, including the premium currency. All players equally get a part of the shared pickups.
The micro-transactions are so low key and not in your face, that I respect them for doing it this way.

Top notch visuals with enemies that show satisfying damage and weakness. Explosions deform the land and leave big craters. Weather changes beautifully. Your character gets muddy and covered in oil/goo appropriately. You can see your ship and the support they send out. The way your cape waves. The detail in crazy sometimes.

Fantastic and detailed sounds. From distant booms, to the empty *plink* noise of your clip.

The music is super on point and knows exactly when to play the right tones.

The weapons and aiming system is a good punchy feel, from the light single handed weapons to the heavy shoulder mounted cannon.

Movement and running around feels satisfying. Diving away from big booms feels heroic and exciting.

The seriousness of your person yelling at a giant crab/bug that it'll never change your way of life... brilliant! 

The minigame they built in to call down support and other goodies during missions is another smart move! 

The Devs said that they have grand plans for this game, and I trust them.

Alright, let's get into the thick of it with Helldivers 2. Strap in, because this game is like if Starship Troopers and your most chaotic laser tag match had a baby, and that baby was raised by a drill sergeant with a sick sense of humour.

You drop into alien worlds hotter than a car seat in the Florida sun, and you're tasked with spreading some good old-fashioned 'democratic' freedom - one bullet at a time. And by 'democratic freedom,' I mean you're unleashing more lead than a pencil factory and causing more explosions than a Michael Bay film festival.

The enemies are about as welcoming as a hornet's nest at a picnic. You've got everything from giant bugs that want to make you their lunch, to cybernetically-enhanced freaks who didn't get the memo that the war's supposed to be fun. And your weapons? They're the kind that make you cackle with glee as you turn aliens into a fine mist.

But here's where it gets good: the friendly fire. Oh, yes, you can absolutely obliterate your buddies by mistake (or not... I don't judge). It turns every mission into a suspenseful game of 'try not to accidentally commit war crimes against your own team.'

And when you're not accidentally taking out your squad, you're calling down supply drops that have a penchant for squashing anyone not paying attention. It's like the game is playing a cosmic joke, and the punchline is always some poor sap getting turned into a pancake.

Helldivers 2 doesn't just up the ante; it steals the whole damn casino. It's a chaotic, co-op masterpiece that's as hilarious as it is hardcore. It gets a chef's kiss from me. Perfect score for making me laugh while I cry in a fetal position, trying not to get stomped by my own supply pod... again.

Customization is also very present in the game so you can mix up your character to better fit your play-style.

The different 'Conditions' on planets along with the different enemies and main objectives, side objectives, and pickup weapons along with the loot that you can find helps the replay value and gives you a reason to explore. (The environments are beautiful btw) I also like that you can change the difficulty so if you're playing solo or you just want a more 'casual' time with the game, you can. (Might not seem like a big deal, but I like that the option is there to make things challenging/easier for you if you want)

The only issues I could address are some disconnection/crashes that could happen while playing (they're patching a lot of them tho, along with increasing server capacity so you can actually play the game!)
Apart from that, especially for the price the game is absolutely worth getting!

Hell yeah, recruitment is open once again! I was hesitant at first because of the higher price tag, but oh boy, they let hell loose in this one. Players are greeted with a great sense of humor à la Starship Troopers. After a very concise tutorial, nothing stops the new recruits from shooting, dying, and spreading freedom.
Here, you get a coherent overall package. Starting with the breathtaking graphics, up to the perfectly fitting soundscapes, even the weapons in the game feel like they all pack a punch. With a steady progression system, the enjoyment of the game is sustained over time as well.
Looking forward to a new race or two (+biomes) in the next few months and some new special abilities and this game will be perfect! A great successor to the first iteration with numerous improvements, I can wholeheartedly recommend this gem for all coop game enthusiasts and Starship Trooper fans!

But there is a PC freezing issue with this game, wherein after closing the game, it completely black screens my PC prompting a hard shut down. Now here's the kicker - booting up my system after all this, I can't get a display. This random bug just completely black screens my PC. The only remedy I've found is to bridge my CMOS pins, or pull my CMOS battery for a while.

[h1][b]9/10 - Excellent[/b][/h1]
Helldivers 2 exceeds expectations on every front. The evolution from Helldivers 1, a top-down shooter, to a third person shooter was an excellent choice to appeal to a massive audience.

Gameplay is a frenetic dance of strategy and chaos. The addition of new enemy types, environments, and mission objectives keeps every engagement feeling fresh and unpredictable. Whether you're battling hordes of bugs on a hostile alien planet or engaging in intense firefights against automatons, each mission is a pulse-pounding thrill ride. What sets Helldivers 2 above other PvE horde shooters is the emphasis on teamwork and coordination. Coordinating airstrikes, calling in reinforcements, and reviving fallen squad members require constant communication and collaboration. There's a sense of camaraderie that develops between you and your squad as you overcome seemingly insurmountable odds to complete missions.

Visually, Helldivers 2 is equally impressive as the alien worlds are beautifully realized, with stunning environmental effects and dynamic lighting adding to the immersion. At this time, the game is missing PC upscaling techniques like DLSS, FSR, and XeSS that would further help performance.

Helldivers 2 does include in-game currency and microtransactions, however Arrowhead Games have designed their Warbond system as cosmetic only. You can find their in-game currency naturally throughout each mission, and this means that you don't have to spend real money to purchase armor and helmets from the super store.

My last minor gripe is that to experience the best of what Helldivers 2 has to offer you should always play with as many people as possible. Playing solo is definitely not as easy or as fun as having additional team members. Otherwise, this game is absolutely worth your time.

This game has awakened something deep inside of me that I have not felt in some time now. Fighting the good fight against the automations and the terminds alongside my fellow Helldivers has awakened my patriotic soul for Super Earth, but more importantly, has enlightened me. For a number of years now, I have seen how triple A games have disrespected their loyal fanbases and have put out garbage titles after garbage titles, year after year. 

This game is bringing together multiple communities together and is truly the beginning of the end of the Console wars. As of writing, I have not seen any toxicity from my fellow helldivers. We share one objective: protect Super Earth. For those on the fence on whether or not they should buy HD2 and are concerned with the queue and other initial bugs, it is worth it and then some. The devs have updated the game nearly every day since I bought the game, and have extended the size of  the queue.

For those brave enough to join in fighting the good fight, welcome to Hell. For Freedom, Liberty, and Democracy!

I've put some more hours into the game recently after having put it down, and although my gripes around spawning remain, I've found that the experience is definitely better with a group of coordinated friends. As with many co-op focused games, it suffers when you have less than a full squad or running with a group of random strangers. I can sympathize (its a hard problem to solve.)

There's a lot of great things about this game. The action is hard hitting and visceral. Guns and stratagems feel awesome and powerful when you're using them. Progression is pretty standard but is a compelling driver to keep playing.

My biggest gripe, and one that ruins a lot of games for me is enemy spawning. They often seem to come out of nowhere, from behind, (or, conveniently, from whatever spot your team did NOT cover with a sentry.) Often they just seem to spawn in a never ending flow with no clear indication of where the next group of enemies is coming from. The entire spawning system for enemies feels cheap and gamey and for me can really spike the frustration meter.

There are mechanics at work here that are not immediately apparent. Stealth tactics are apparently a thing, but it's not easy to discern when you're employing them effectively. The game makes you really want to shoot every enemy you encounter, but the more I play the more I realize this is a sure path to being overwhelmed.

The servers are often full and it can be difficult to get into a game. I've had the most luck joining a friends game straight from my Steam friends list. I have to imagine they are working hard to remedy this. Having a game that so many people want to play that it overwhelms your servers is a good problem to have for a dev, so long as you fix the issue fast before people throw up their hands in frustration and move on.

So, yeah, I've got m,y gripes but it's definitely worth checking out.

Update: The servers seem to be working just fine now. I have been able to get into the game over the last few days without any waiting at all.

The game itself is a lot of fun and I do recommend it already, but it also has some issues. Some of which are hopefully quick fixes. Others probably not so much.

The good is pretty much everywhere at this point so I won't dwell on it too much. The coop is well done and performs smoothly. The gameplay loops are engaging without being tedious. Progression is based on resources that don't have much of an overlap so you can save for a new gun for example without compromising how quickly you can unlock a new turret or whatever. Teamplay is encouraged heavily, but not to the point where having a random on the team without a mic is going to ruin anything.

Basically, go check out some gameplay. Seeing it in action will tell you more than I can here.

The negatives though seem to be fairly glossed over by the weird LARP filled hype surrounding the game at the moment. And some of them are pretty nasty.

First and foremost, the stats listed in the game for various things are wrong. The devs have acknowledged that the player armor is bugged (heavy protects as well as light), but I haven't seen anything about weapons. And they seem to be just as screwed. The armor penetration stat for example seems to have little to nothing to do with how well a round can actually penetrate enemy armor. Damage is another stat that needs a pass.

Speaking of passes, everything in this game is in desperate need of a balance pass. As it stands right now the best weapon in terms of stopping power and ammo efficiency is the fourth primary players unlock. But yet absolutely nothing else comes anywhere close. And it's the same with strategems as well. Some are just wildly better or worse than the others.

On a much lower level of priority, the anticheat needs to detect macros. I'm not suggesting banning the players that use them, it is a PvE game after all, but put them in their own pool for quickplay. Players that chase the meta as a skill crutch are one thing, we've all been there at some point, but those who "min-max" so hard that they need a third party tool to remove entire gameplay elements are on a whole different level and can/should be relegated to playing with only their peers.

This game has a pretty face and a well made ad campaign... but underneath the surface this game is ugly with zero campaign. to start off, the game literally tells you that it wants you to remain stationary in order to be accurate in shooting 3rd person (which is default and the best option) however if you go to first person your aiming becomes somewhat manageable with the drawback that you cannot see a damn thing besides your scope in front of you. the "customization" or lack thereof comprises of bland mustard colors in different stripes and different stratagems to use in combat of which you can only hold so many, which brings me to the online component... the game is unplayable solo and you are basically forced to play with randoms who will probably using your same stratagems until you finish a 40 minute mission and return to the ship and coordinate... as long as they dont immediately leave or get kicked. the environments CAN be interesting but the early 2010s graphics really hold it back and they try to mask that with awful looking weather effects. the weapon magazines are incredibly small, do not auto reload, and if your mag is not empty when reloading you lose any ammo in it which forces you to click til you hear a click and then go through a painfully long reload animation while being bombarded by enemies. enemies mind you that do not stop, are faster than you, and deal incredible damage while you have no regen and only stims that you cannot administer while under attack. i cant say enough bad things about this game... maybe for $10 id pick it back up because im self destructive... but then id probably even regret that too.

TLDR: One of the finest coop multiplayer games, I've ever played.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Update 24.02.2024:

>> Online is working without issues now (at least for the last 2 days)

>> I've erned enough of the premium currency to unlock the battle pass, which is a clear sign, that against my initial thoughts, you don't need to put in extra money to get things out of that pass as well

>> Performance in general enhanced a bit, this is coming especially handy for Steam Deck players, since the game now runs in a acceptable frame rate & quality. Battey drain is huge though. 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Update 09.02.2024:

>> Online Matchmaking is now functional!

>> Today, I successfully played the game on the Steam Deck using GE Proton 8.25 (although an update to 8.30 is recommended, as it should work the same way).

In-game settings optimized: set everything to mid, shadows to low, and activated performance mode.
= Achieved 35 - 40 fps in the Tutorial at full TDP, but it's essential to consider the potential impact on battery life.

>> The only thing I will miss is that there are no tanks, mechs or anything like this in the game right now. I would include something which is only operational for at least two people (like the tank in H1).

>> There is no longer any reason not to recommend the game, except for the questionable inclusion of a Premium Battle Pass in a paid game.

>> More details about the Battle Pass:
There are two "Tiers":
-> Free Tier: Accessible to everyone, offering new cosmetics and weapons.
-> Paid Tier: Requires real currency and provides different/additional cosmetics and weapons.

The free pass offers significantly more content to unlock compared to the paid version. However, there is a possibility that the weapons in the paid pass might be stronger, potentially leading to a "Pay2Win" scenario. This aspect needs ongoing evaluation.

Players can earn currency to unlock the premium battle pass by playing and unlocking items in the free one. Despite unlocking all currency packages, it remains insufficient to purchase the premium pass (you receive 750 and need 1000). Nevertheless, the system may allow players to achieve this in "Season 2" if the mechanics remain unchanged.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Initial game feedback from 08.02.2024:

>> The game was completely non-functional on the Steam Deck.
>> Online gaming was inaccessible.
>> The controversial Battle Pass system was present and operational.
>> Tanks, Mechs, and other elements were notably missing.

Obviously there was Helldivers 1. But if you remember hearing about or seeing anything about Second Extinction this game feels a lot like that one. Minus weapon customization and the freedom to roam the map without the looming threat of being abandoned after x amount of time. 

The game could definitely benefit from some weapon customization such as expanded ammo reserves, more dmg, better accuracy, explosive rounds, etc all attached to the weapon itself. So you can take any weapon that may start off kind of meh and turn it into a killing machine. (Not an automaton those things can rust as scrap heaps.) But yea just another small thing to work towards to keep the game fresh longer.

In conclusion here though. The game is great. Punching your friends off the extract terminal to be the one to call it down is hilariously good fun. Diving off every possible ledge or rock you can is entertaining beyond measure. Taking 3x as much damage from doing so when you just watched your ally take none is also hilarious. All in all a really fun and really enjoyable experience. Buy this game now.

First thing's first - This is more of a neutral review than a negative one. But it's not something I can recommend for this price tag. Go mod a certain 2010s-era game until you're happy, or buy it only on sale.

Disclaimer: I've not played the first Helldiver and don't plan to.

This game has [b] a lot [/b] of technical issues. We'll get to that soon.

[u] The positives! [/u]
- Some of the best gore mechanics in a shooter game. Bugs and robots alike blow apart and die in a visceral and violent manner that puts every other game to shame.

- Gunplay system that works well, simulating weapon sway and recoil in an intuitive manner without exaggerating either. Different weapons have different turn speeds, so you can't swing around a full sized MG and flickshot three bugs.

- Fun setting that encourages teamwork and cooperation.

- Solid ragdoll system and diving system. Diving is like dodging, but leaves you prone afterwards. This feels well-designed, as it's a quick way to remove a player from the enemy's reach, or move the player behind cover.

- Fun objective system. Unlike most games that forces you to do some tedious work, most of the objectives are done by operating a panel, similar to Alien Swarm, but you use the Konami code instead. It's fun when you get the hang of it.

- A solid weapon "setting" system. You can set your sniper scope for different ranges, or your machine gun for different fire rates. It stands out because not many games allow you to do this.

[u] The Negatives. There's a lot. [/u]

- Unlocking items is done by earning Medals. Which is earned by playing the game. Unlocking requires you to spend it on a battle pass. (It's free). The grind that comes with it is atrocious, exacerbated by a page system. For example, "page 3 items" cannot be unlocked until you spend about 40 medals elsewhere. The numbers get ludicrous the further you get.

- Extremely poor readability. This is a long one, so bear with me.

Good games typically teach you how the game works without any hand-holding. For example, Killing Floor features Fleshpounds that have glowy chests that acts as an alternative headshot point. This game does not even try to hint where the weakpoints are. Sometimes, you have to shoot a bug in the face. Sometimes, it's under its body. Other times, the weakpoints are stored in the [strike] balls [/strike] butt.

Games such as Deep Rock Galactic, Left 4 Dead 2, World War Z often indicate weakpoints either by using the familiar shape of a humanoid, a glowy body part, or visible material differences.

Pop quiz! Hitmarkers in most games come in different colors for different purposes, such as hits, kills, armored hits, and so on. What practical difference does a RED or WHITE hitmarker in Helldivers 2 make? None. Red hitmarkers do not mean kills. White hitmarkers don't, either.

There are way too many small problems in the core gameplay that stacks up, but it's tolerable if you don't care, don't mind, or have a full team.

Smol, quick list of 'things the games won't help you understand'
Weakpoints, Audio / Visual Cues, How-to-juke-enemy-that-is-constantly-in-your-face-because-you're-solo.

- Bullet sponge enemies. Crit spots exist, but the game doesn't try to teach you anything. Hitmarkers aren't very illuminating.

- Shoddy weapon balancing. There's barely any reason to use any other weapon once you unlock the automatic shotgun. At this time of writing, marksman weapons do not pierce medium armor, meaning they aren't much better than assault rifles. The pump action shotgun has insufficient ammo for its damage output compared to the autoshotgun. The SMG feels better than the rifle in every way. It almost makes the "weapon settings" moot, unfortunately. It'd be nice to see every weapon get buffed to match the autoshotgun.

- Horrendous difficulty without a full team. Enemies will swarm you endlessly unless you have a full team. Diving doesn't help when you have 18 bugs surrounding you, and you can't use your support items (called stratagems) while moving.

- Melee is weak. Weak enough that I forget it exists.

[b] Technical Issues [/b]
- Depending on time of day, you'll be unable to play the game because the servers are drowning in players. Yep. As if the "Always Online" system isn't bad enough, there's a chance the servers are "at capacity".

- Black Screen on Startup. This happens alarmingly often.

- Crashes. They happen semi frequently. This can render 5-30 minutes of intense and rewarding gameplay into a really bad case of blueballing.

- A lot of bugs. Ranging from "terminals don't work properly" to "player cannot respawn even when a reinforcement stratagem is thrown down" to "primary weapon is missing mid-game."

- nProtect Anticheat. I'm not too well versed with it, but it needs to be said that this is a tremendously invasive anticheat. Words like "Rootkit" will start being thrown around. Why would a coop game need such an anticheat? Even competitive games don't go this far. It's overkill for little to no benefit other than "less cheaters". It's not CS2 or Escape From Tarkov, cheaters aren't going to damage this game that badly.

What sets HellDivers 2 apart is its emphasis on teamwork and strategy. The game cleverly designs missions that require genuine cooperation, pushing players to communicate effectively, plan their moves, and execute with precision. The variety of enemies, each with unique behaviors and weaknesses, keeps the gameplay fresh and demands adaptive strategies.

Graphically, HellDivers 2 is a masterpiece. The attention to detail in the alien landscapes and the design of the HellDivers and their equipment is nothing short of spectacular. Coupled with an atmospheric soundtrack that perfectly complements the intensity of the battles, the game delivers a sensory feast.

Moreover, the developers have committed to supporting the game post-launch, promising an array of updates, new content, and community-driven events that will surely keep the player base engaged for years to come.

Game is good. They successfully ported Helldivers to Third-Person and created a fun, engaging CO-OP Third Person Shooter that I enjoyed playing for the time I did and can't wait to play more with friends.

Game ran decently well for me despite not dl'ing most up-to-date drivers for my gfx card. No crashes and played the tutorial + 2 missions. Got a consistent 80+ fps at Ultra/1440P even with lots of enemies and explosions but I would've been disappointed if that wasn't the case. 

That being said, I don't like the anti-cheat so will be refunding and waiting until they find a different solution. NProtect has had exploits in the past (https://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2005-0295/) and is probably the cheapest and most "suspect" of the big K-level anti-cheat systems (nProtect, EAC, Riot's solution). Kernel level anti-cheat is a big no-no for me and I had wished Arrowhead would've used a solution held in higher regard.

Server issues continue to be a consistent issue. Mission rewards  have been broken since 2/10 and the ability to matchmake and play with friends has been spotty since launch. They have paused joining the official discord servers due to the influx of new players. Also, despite the anti-cheat, there have been cheaters with infinite ammo, infinite samples, etc since launch. 

Edit 2/24/24:

I'm changing my review to recommended as most of the issues have been fixed: server issues, mission rewards, matchmaking, crashes, etc. I'm still not a fan of the third-rate anticheat but it hasn't stopped me from playing the game and really enjoying it. I just want to highlight the issues/concerns there so folks can make an educated decision for themselves.

GPU: 6800xt Nitro+
MEM: 128 GB @ 3600mhz
DISK: 1TB NVME

Overall this game is really fun and I highly recommend it. There's a ton that goes in to understanding this game and that makes it some much better. From customizing your hell diver gear trying to stand out and unlocking weapons and equipment. All the way to naming your ship and upgrading your home defenses. My first game in with my best friend I was absolutely hooked. Just imagine destroying the Galaxy of robots while fighting termites at the same time with your boy. As far as the environment goes there's so many different planets and I mean so so many different planets that the environments are all different and that just makes it really immersive and honestly really cool.

Servers- At first the servers were having some issues, sometimes you will get kicked out of games but but now it definitely seems like they're putting the work in to fix all that. It is understandable though to have some disconnections because this is such a popular game an it is brand new so it's good to give the developers time to get everything in the works. Feel like I've had this game for a good substantial time now and it does seem like the servers are a ton better now .

HellDivers 2 plays like an older AAA game.

In other words, when a AAA company *USED* to make a game for the sake of making a proper game, rather than a tax write off or a political statement.

HellDivers 2 hasn't done any piece of the falsified advertisement that Ubisoft titles have because, thankfully, Arrowhead Studios appears to have a CEO that is not as literally in-bred as the one running companies EA and Ubisoft.


HellDivers 2 is a third-person, first-person hybrid shooter where the players are THE ((Totally over-glorified suicide unit)) "Super Earth's Greatest military specialist unit" 

It has a lot of very tiny graphical details that surprise me, but would take to long to talk about (Capes float on water, clothing gets covered in grime, boots imprint into things)

But the game-play is a very solid, partially challenging, arcade like SOCOM shooter, or can be if you sneak around the missions rather than literally kill the first thing that moves.

Missions range from Defense and Offense, and all of them are timed. The players get an array of weapons and cosmetics which can be unlocked using Tokens received at the end of missions and going through a Battle-pass like system. There are two systems

One is premium and paid for (I think like eight bucks? Don't quote me on that, it's 1000 SC in game) and the other is free. The weapons in the Premium pass are actually well balanced to the ones you get in the free pass.
The Liberator Explosive adds stagger against some enemies, while the Liberator default add better precision damage and higher capacity, for example.

Alongside guns, the players have strategic call-downs that can be entered by playing Dance Dance Revolution.

These call-downs range from specialty weapons, to fortifications, to drones, to Turrets, to bombardments and even a F16-like fighter craft that can do everything but send you a thermos full of coffee (But I bet they would and could if you could ask nicely)

There are two enemy factions

Bugs

Robots.

I definitely recommend this game as it stands at the moment now that the servers have been expanded to allow 700 000 players

Aside from the nProtect Gameguard, which by itself is basically malware, the game has a myriad of other issues that make it frustrating to play.  There are constant issues with matchmaking that prevent you from ever playing with others or cause the game to crash when you try to quick play.  There are other weird bugs like the flamethrower burning yourself if you try to use it while walking forward or objective markers randomly moving around. 

All that being said the gameplay itself is also quite clunky.  Your character doesn't respond to your controls right away like one would expect from any FPS.  This is by design though but it ends up feeling really clunky as you can't aim properly just due to how the game works.

I would not recommend this game in its current state.

Editing review, as the devs boosted capacity sooner than it had sounded like they would be able to.

As of this writing there is a significant bug with their in-game FPS limiter, which will drive many systems' CPUs to overheat. Disabling this and using the FPS limiter in your GPU software will greatly reduce crashes. That said, I have had some in-game crashes still, but they are no longer occurring on the majority of missions.

The game is fun, and I'm glad to see the devs are resolving launch issues faster than expected.

This game is a gem- And here is why I think so DESPITE all the current bugs, and issues, and problems.
Keep note- this is my personal opinion, I'm not some game critique, not some salesmen- hell this is the only game I EVER made a SERIOUS review on in such a state, if at all!

The good.
First of all- I absolutely LOVE the amount of effort that went into the character movement- while currently a little wonky, Just that satisfying feeling of dodging and shooting- It hits that Cinematic vibe- Like you're in an action movie, EVERY damn session! The music, the effects- the explosions, Every mission feels.. Different then the last one, with it's own share of hard moments- and easy moments, Some moments where a random idea to hit that broken down hellbomb netted me a good 20 bugs!, Or struggling as the last man alive on the escape platform, Broken arm and bleeding chest- Blocked by my DRIPPY AS HELL armor as im fending off enemies with my revolver- My last weapon, each shot mattered- With no reinforces avaliable as my squadmates were rooting for me, and I did it- Barely, with one HP, but I did!, and it felt AMAZING! Like I was some legendary war hero- Before I accidentaly shot the floor with an autocannon and became the dunce of the group. Even SOLO im having fun running low difficulty missions- taking whatever loadout I want, From the godlike breaker- to the regular assault rifle, and a whole SLEW of stratagems to tackle whatever playstyle I currently wish to take- I even made an Electroboom inspired loadout - Tesla tower, Arc thrower, Incindiary breaker, and flame grenades, I call it the Shortcircuit! And it's a whole lotta fun! Even if you can teamkill at any given moment- I still manage to do it just fine! But enough of my ramblings, Now to the less pleasant part.

The bads - As of currently, the current player limit hit 700k, But people are just so.. Ugh, Impatiant!, I get it- you bought a game that looked cool, or a friend reccomended- or maybe you are a long time veteran of Helldivers one, which had --- A 7K PLAYERBASE ISH ---, People refuse to understand that game development and fixes take a bit of TIME to dish out- and that under such pressure, It's so DIFFICULT, Hell- the discord server looked like a clown fiesta in the first few days, People raging left and right- the game getting review bombed- and still, I get your anger, it has a justified place- You want to get what you paid for, But keep in mind- the developers planned, for BEST CASE SCENARIO- 250k players, and no more. instead- on the first week, we have nearly half a million people wanting to log on to play this BANGER of a game, Coupled with many errors that suddenly popped up- be it because the servers were frying in the background, or from issues that were not discovered just yet- Like some error codes for the PS, or.. the fact that chargers sometimes just enjoy climbing vertically on walls instead of slamming into them. amongst a few game-breaking bugs that straight up crash you- and the horrendous login errors that sometimes require you to restart your router, and give you so much ANNOYENCE- I beg of you, if you see this review, and you posted a negative one- Think about it again in a good month or two, Let the game become more stable once more because there is PLENTY of stuff to fix- and the devs are well aware, With- or without people running around screaming their heads off like headless commander bugs. unlike a lot of other devs- they honestly had a pretty solid argument- atleast for the connection issues. and giving this godlike game- yes, GODLIKE- (In my view, again, personal opinio) a NEGATIVE review because you don't have the patiance to wait a bit for the devs to fix some issues- in this game which is just.. so much FUN? That's on you chief. Just make sure to change your review in a month, maybe few- after many stuff is fixed- and added to this glorious game.

And please- take everything I said with a grain of salt, I don't mean to invoke the wrath of some professional game critiques, or people who had REALLY bad experiences with the game and nearly barely played, This is just my personal very detailed opinion on this game, Which I honestly LOVE. really, REALLY love!.
